children.subject: Why do you think people hate CS 61B taking it with him?

I took 61b with Hilfinger, and his lectures can be very dense, and are not necessarily the best at teaching core content. Therefore, people don't enjoy the data structures as much since his lectures aren't as engaging as Hug's. Also, some people struggle with the projects–they can't get through them on their own, they have trouble debugging, etc. Hilfinger's style isn't for everybody, but a lot of people like his project over exam emphasis. It really depends on what you prefer, thus the love/hate relationship.
I took 61b with Hilfinger and loved it. I think his projects forces one to become a better programmer.

+1 to above response. I loved his project-oriented style, and I wish more courses at Cal were project-oriented rather than exam-oriented. I learnt so much more than I did from any other course with its usual weekly pset bs.

I didn't love taking 61b with Hilfinger but my goodness I learned a shit ton. 

The projects were certainly really stressful (and there was some logistical issues), but since I am a person that learns so much more course content doing hws/projects than studying for tests, each project made me really learn the subject it was trying to test me. I also appreciate this style because as a person who usually only does average on CS-style tests, the project focus allowed me to focus on really learning the concepts, and the huge amount of work I put into projects (I spent about 4 weeks on the gitlet project, including the entirety of dead week, but I really understood gitlet afterward) was reflected in my grade. 

His lectures weren't amazing but also far from the worst I've had. 

I already knew that data structures wasn't really my thing while taking the course, so I can't speak as to whether he affected that, but I did value the incredible amount of content I learned while taking it from him.

When I first came to Berkeley I heard a lot of bad things about Hilfinger that turned out not to be true. 

He's fine. I took 61a and 61b with him.

Hug is fine. I used his lectures to study. 

They're both fine. It depends on your dedication to the class, not the professor. Though this is not true for every class, it's true for this one. 

And, overall, when you compare anyone to someone else whose last name is Hug, they lose every time!

Took 61B with Hug and it was the best decision I've ever made. I consider myself a really terrible test-taker, but I really depend on lectures to learn so I didn't want to gamble with Hilfinger lectures and didn't want to give up my entire life over projects.

I don't think it's that much harder overall to get a good grade in Hug's class than it is in Hilfinger's course; both versions will take a good amount of work. I think you will almost certainly like the material and experience more with Hug. 


61B is a really important class, and it's far better to understand the material really well than to try to game the system to declare. You will be fine attempting to declare with Hug's 61B (in fact, when I needed to appeal my CS application, Josh was the first person I turned to for a letter of recommendation :)) )

I highly highly highly recommend taking the class with Hug.  I had a rough time in 61A (since I came in with not much CS experience) and I was pretty concerned about declaring, but 61B with Hug completely changed that.  He's so friendly and caring towards his students, and he genuinely cares about making sure his students succeed, which I think is more than you can say about many professors.  He's an amazing teacher and does an excellent job explaining 61B concepts (which I would say are some of the most important concepts that you'll get here in Berkeley CS classes).  His projects are challenging but rewarding in that you build something cool while learning a lot of important concepts, and you feel like a great programmer when you're done with the class.

Some people say that his exams are harder, and it is true that his exams are worth more than Hilfiinger's, but he gives very fair exams, and if you study hard, you will do well.  As someone who struggled quite a bit with 61A exams, I know that it may seem daunting to pick a class that people say has harder exams, but if you put in the time, you will learn a lot more with Hug.  And ultimately, if you're interested in going into industry, you need to really understand data structures, so I personally, think it's a lot more worthwhile to actually learn the material through better lectures and more time spent prepping for midterms.

61B with Hug was the class that actually built up my confidence and coding ability, and I would recommend his class to anyone :)

history.content:
IMO, Hilfinger period. Hug is making me hate it

---------

Wtf is the above student response? Hug is literally the best educator at Cal by a long shot. His lectures are literally the best part of my day, and I feel so happy and we'll educated after them. He's really made me think about life and CS in a fun way, and I feel my Berkeley experience would be lacking without him.

Now, I can't speak for Hilfinger, but it would be a huge mistake to not take it with Hug just for the grade. Fwiw, I'm on track for an A+, and if you engage with the material I'm sure you'll do great. And in the process, you progress by not just coasting along but actually thriving and learning a lot.
IMO, Hilfinger period. Hug is making me hate it

children.subject: 61B with Hilfinger is a great class, and that's all I can say.

history.content:
I know it's a lot easier to get an A in his course vs Hug, but I heard people hate CS taking his class. Is this true?

If someone wants to declare but also wants to enjoy 61B, should they take Hilfinger or Hug?
history.subject: Is Hilfinger Worth Taking For 61B
